fields.name: calibrate
fields.description: A CALIBRATION needs to be done for any heterodyne observation in order to get data with a calibrated intensity scale. It is normally done before the target observations. It must always be done after changing receiver and/or backend setups. It should also be done when changing sources and often enough to follow any variation of the athmosphere, about every 15 minutes. In a standard calibration for heterodyne receivers, we observe 3 subscans: on a sky position, an ambient temperature load (a.k.a., "hot" load), and a "cold" load at about the temperature of liquid nitrogen.

fields.name: pointing
fields.description: POINTING observations are done to optimize the positioning of the telescope in Azimuth and Elevation. This is normally done by continuum observations of a cross scan in Azimuth and Elevation on a point source (or at least a small source) near the intended target source.

fields.name: focus
fields.description: FOCUS measurements are done to optimize the position of the subreflector (secondary) along the telescope axis by maximizing the intensity of the radiation focussed into the receiver(s). It is best done on a strong point source, e.g., on a planet if or when it's angular diameter is less than the beam width at the frequency to be observed. It is strongly recommended to do a POINTING on the same source before a FOCUS.

fields.name: tip
fields.description: TIP (antenna tipping or "skydip") observations are done to measure the transmission of the Earth's athmosphere, by taking data at several points with the same Azimuth but different Elevations, spaced by equal steps in "air mass".

fields.name: onOff
fields.description: Subscans are taken alternating between a position that's considered to be "ON-source" and a reference position that's normally assumed to be"OFF-source", i.e., free of emission.

fields.name: onTheFlyMap
fields.description: In OTFMAP (on-the-fly) observations, the antenna moves relative to the source while recording its position and taking data a high rate, thus performing "scans" in the strict sense of the word. This is a very fast mode for mapping extended regions.

fields.name: track
fields.description: The TRACK observing mode simply tracks one position that is fixed relative to the source. It is normally used with Frequency Switching.

fields.name: VLBI
fields.description: VLBI is a special observing mode to track the source position specified with SOURCE during VLBI scans.
Software for setting/running the observations at the IRAM-30m

fields.name: A100
fields.description: 3mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 80 and 115.5 GHz.

fields.name: A230
fields.description: 1mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 197 and 266 GHz.

fields.name: B100
fields.description: 3mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 81 and 115.5 GHz.

fields.name: B230
fields.description: 1mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 197 and 266 GHz.

fields.name: C150
fields.description: 2mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 130 and 183 GHz.

fields.name: C270
fields.description: 1mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 241 and 281 GHz.

fields.name: D150
fields.description: 2mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 130 and 183 GHz.

fields.name: D270
fields.description: 1mm heterodyne receiver tunable between 241 and 281 GHz.

fields.name: MAMBO1
fields.description: 37 bolometer array at 1mm from the MPIfR.

fields.name: MAMBO2
fields.description: 117 bolometer array at 1mm from the MPIfR.

fields.name: HERA1 Pixel 1
fields.description: Pixel 1 of the HEterodyne Receivers Array (HERA). Vertical component, tunable between 215 and 241 GHz.

fields.name: HERA1 Pixel 2
fields.description: Pixel 2 of the HEterodyne Receivers Array (HERA). Vertical component, tunable between 215 and 241 GHz.

fields.name: HERA2 Pixel 1
fields.description: Pixel 1 of the HEterodyne Receivers Array (HERA). Horizontal component, tunable between 215 and 272 GHz.

fields.name: HERA2 Pixel 2
fields.description: Pixel 2 of the HEterodyne Receivers Array (HERA). Horizontal component, tunable between 215 and 272 GHz.

fields.name: totalPower
fields.description: Refers simply to data acquisition without any of the other 3 fast Switching Modes. Normally, when using Total Power one or several positions "ON" the source are observed alternating with one or several "OFF"-source reference positions, and the signal is calculated as the difference between "ON" and "OFF".

fields.name: beamSwitching
fields.description: Is done through a rotating chopper wheel in the receiver cabin, which during each rotation (= switching cycle) moves 2 reflecting blades into the beam path in front of the 4th mirror. The offset, rotation period, and blanking times are fixed.Beam Switching is normally only used for POINTING and FOCUS. The source signal is calculated as difference between the direct and offset phases.

fields.name: wobblerSwitching
fields.description: During this switching mode, the wobbling secondary mirror is switched between 2 positions, which are offset from the telescope axis by a fixed amount. Wobbler Switching is normally used with ONOFF or, for bolometer continuum mapping, with OTFMAP.

fields.name: frequencySwitching
fields.description: Switches between 2 different frequencies, so that there are 2 phases. The (source) signal is calculated as the difference between these 2 phases. Frequency Switching is normally used with TRACK or OTFMAP.

fields.name: Continuum
fields.description: Continuum backend 1 channel per receiver.

fields.name: 4MHz
fields.description: Physically, there are a total of 9 4MHz filterbanks, each with a fixed resolution of 4MHz and bandwidth of 1024 MHz.

fields.name: 1MHz
fields.description: The 1MHz filterbank can be used with 1, 2, 3, or 4 parts with 256, 512, 768, or 1024 MHz bandwidth; but the total number of 1MHz channels is limited to 1024.

fields.name: 100kHz
fields.description: The 100kHz filterbank can be used in one part with 25.3 MHz bandwidth, or in 2 parts each with 12.8 MHz bandwidth.

fields.name: WILMA
fields.description: WILMA has a fixed resolution of 2 MHz and bandwidth of 1024 MHz (theoretical), of which about 930 MHz are practically usable. 2 WILMA parts (times 9) can be connected to HERA1 and/or HERA2.

fields.name: VESPA
fields.description: VESPA allows many different resolutions and bandwidths, depending the "mode" used. For details see the VESPA user's guide.

fields.name: ABBA
fields.description: Backend ABBA (Adc Bolometer BAckend) for the Mambo and Mambo2 photometers data acquisition from the Max-Planck-Institut fur Radioastronomie.

fields.name: Hera
fields.description: Observing with the Hera receiver.

fields.name: Bolometer
fields.description: Observing with bolometer.

fields.name: Heterodyne
fields.description: Observing with the heterodyne receivers.

fields.name: Technical Problem
fields.description: Telescope stopped due to a technical problem.

fields.name: Bad weather
fields.description: Telescope stopped due to bad weather.

fields.name: Maintenance
fields.description: Maintenance of the IRAM-30m.

fields.name: BoloMap
fields.description: OTF maps with the bolometer for the project.

fields.name: BoloOnOff
fields.description: On-Off integration on a point source with the bolometer for the project.

fields.name: SIS
fields.description: Integration with heterodyne receivers for the project.

fields.name: HERA
fields.description: Integration with the HERA receiver for the project.

fields.name: projection
fields.description: The standard simple "radio" projection offsets in the chosen coordinate system. This is normally the astronomical system of offsets in which point-by-point (TRACK, ONOFF) or on-the-fly (OTFMAP) maps are made.

fields.name: horizontalTrue
fields.description: The horizontal system with a factor 1/cos(elevation) applied to the azimuth offset. This is the system in which OTF maps with Wobbler switching and the bolometer are normally done.

fields.name: nasmyth
fields.description: System with the special offsets in the Nasmyth reference to point an off-center pixel of a focal-plane array receiver (bolometer, HERA) to the commanded astronomical position, e.g., to use an off-center pixel for pointing, focus, ONOFF.
